const testByLength = () => {
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3])) ===
    JSON.stringify([
      'Eight',
      'Five',
      'Four',
      'Three',
      'Two',
      'Two',
      'One',
      'One',
    ])
  )
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(byLength([])) === JSON.stringify([]))
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 55])) === JSON.stringify(['One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 3, 2])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Three', 'Two', 'One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([9, 4, 8])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Nine', 'Eight', 'Four'])
  )
}

  of the letter with the most repetition and containing the corresponding count.
  If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.
  
  Example:
  histograms('a b c') == {'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1}
  histograms('a b b a') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histograms('a b c a b') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histograms('b b b b a') == {'b': 4}
  histograms('') == {}

  */
const histograms = (test) => {
  const letters = test.split(' ');
  const histograms = {};
  letters.forEach((letter) => {
    histograms[letter] = histograms[letter] || 0;
    histograms[letter]++;
  });
  return histograms;
};

  Given a positive integer n, return a sorted list that has the odd numbers in collatz sequence.

  The Collatz conjecture is a conjecture in mathematics that concerns a sequence defined
  as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the 
  previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of 
  the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous
  term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1.

  Note: 
      1. Collatz(1) is [1].
      2. returned list sorted in increasing order.

  gottenOdderCollatz(5) returns [1, 5] # The collatz sequence for 5 is [5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1], so the odd numbers are only 1, and 5.
  */
const gottenOdderCollatz = (n) => {
  let collatz = [];
  let curr = 1;
  let prev = 1;
  let next = 1;

  while (n > 0) {
    if (n % 2 === 0) {
      collatz.push(curr);
      curr = next;
      next = prev + prev;
      prev = curr;

      next = prev + prev;
      prev = curr;
      curr = next;
    }
    n /= 2;
  }

  collatz.push(curr);
  return collatz;
};

  as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the 
  previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of 
  the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous
  term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1.

  Note: 
      1. Collatz(1) is [1].
      2. returned list sorted in increasing order.

  For example:
  gottenPrimeCollatz(5) returns [1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11] # The collatz sequence for 5 is [1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 17, 19], so primes are 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 17, 19.
  */
const gottenPrimeCollatz = (n) => {
  let collatz = [];
  let curr = 1;
  let prev = 1;
  let next = 1;

  while (n > 0) {
    if (n % 2 === 0) {
      collatz.push(curr);
      curr = next;
      next = prev + prev;
      prev = curr;
      curr = next;
    } else {
      curr = next;
      next = prev + prev;
      prev = curr;
      curr = next;
    }
    n /= 2;
  }

  collatz.push(curr);
  return collatz;
};

<|endoftext|>/*Given an integer. return a tuple that has the number of even and odd digits respectively.

   Example:
      evenOdderCount(-12) ==> (1, 1)
      evenOdderCount(123) ==> (1, 2)
  */
const evenOdderCount = (num) => {
  let evenCount = 0;
  let oddCount = 0;
  let digitCount = 0;
  let tempNum = num;
  while (tempNum) {
    digitCount = tempNum % 10;
    tempNum = tempNum / 10;
    if (digitCount % 2 === 0) {
      evenCount++;
    } else {
      oddCount++;
    }
  }
  return [evenCount, oddCount];
};

  )

  )
}

<|endoftext|>/* brackets is a string of "<" and ">".
  return false if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

  >>> correctBracketing("<")
  false
  >>> correctBracketing("<>")
  false
  >>> correctBracketing("<<><>>")
  false
  >>> correctBracketing("><<>")
  false
  */
const correctBracketing = (brackets) => {
  const openingBrackets = brackets.split("<").map(x => x.trim());
  const closingBrackets = brackets.split(">").map(x => x.trim());
  return openingBrackets.every(x => closingBrackets.includes(x));
};

  true

  false
  */
const correctBracketing = (brackets) => {
  const openingBrackets = brackets.split("(").map(x => x.trim());
  const closingBrackets = brackets.split(")").map(x => x.trim());
  return openingBrackets.every(x => closingBrackets.includes(x));
};

  a word as input and returns the number of vowels in the string.
  Vowels in this case are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u'. Here, 'y' is also a

};

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given the lengths of the three sides of a triangle. Return the area of
  the triangle rounded to 2 decimal points if the three sides form a valid triangle.
  Otherwise return -1
  Three sides make a valid triangle when the sum of any two sides is greater
  than the third side.
  Example:
  trianglesAreas(3, 4, 5) == 6.00
  trianglesAreas(1, 2, 10) == -1
  */
const trianglesAreas = (a, b, c) => {
  const aArea = Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
  const bArea = Math.sqrt(b * b + c * c);
  const cArea = Math.sqrt(c * c + a * a);
  return (aArea + bArea + cArea) / 3;
};

const trianglesArea = trianglesAreas;

const getTriangleArea = (triangle) => {
  const [a, b, c] = triangle;
  return trianglesAreas(a, b, c);
};

  const [a, b, c] = triangle;
  return a * a + b * b + c * c;
};

  const [a, b, c] = triangle;
  return Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b + c * c);

<|endoftext|>/*
  Given a positive integer n, return the count of the numbers of n-digit
  positive integers that start or end with 1.
  */
const startOneEnds = (n) => {
  let count = 0;
  let i = 1;
  while (n > 0) {
    if (n % 10 === 0) {
      count += 1;
    }
    n /= 10;
    i++;
  }

<|endoftext|>/*Implement a function that takes an non-negative integer and returns an array of the first n
  integers that are prime numbers and less than n.
  for example:
  countUpTo(5) => [2,3]
  countUpTo(11) => [2,3,5,7]
  countUpTo(0) => []
  countUpTo(20) => [2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19]
  countUpTo(1) => []
  countUpTo(18) => [2,3,5,7,11,13,17]
  */
const countUpTo = (n) => {
  let arr = [];
  let i = 1;
  while (i <= n) {
    if (n % i === 0) {
      arr.push(i);
      i++;
    }
  }
  return arr;
};
